Dear Ms. Canales:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 23, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s
performance annually thereafter.
One of ten new employee files and one of four employee files who have been
employed for more than one year performance evaluation.
2

CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers
• (1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and volunteer
who has contact with residents 4 or more hours
per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is
free from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom
from communicable tuberculosis shall be verified
within the 1 year period before employment and
shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of ten new employee files documented after employment the employee was
screened for tuberculosis. Two of four employee files who have been employed for
more than one year lacked tuberculosis screening documentation showing the
employee was screened one year later.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 04/03/2023

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
3

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 6 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
2023 Renewal: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period as
a result of the Renewal inspection completed on 2/08/2023. This CAP contained
violations for references completed after an employee was hired, not having any
documentation for a TB test, and an employee not having the yearly training for
Safe Crisis Management. The agency set up a reminder tickler sysytem to keep
track of deadlines and implemented a quarterly monitoring report to check and
maintain compliance. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action
steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP complaince with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2023C0000271 with CAP approval date of 4/17/2023 was a
result of staff not being up to date on Safe Crisis Management training. The
agency updated their policy to reflect the annual requirement of training and a
system to notify employees within two months of their recertification requirements
by email with available dates of training. The agency is currently complying with
the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP complaince with no
noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2023C0000339 with CAP approval date of 5/17/2023 was a
result of the facility not completing separate incident reports for a youth’s restraints.
The Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) or Facility Administrator (FA) will review
all incident reports within 24 hours ensuring there are separate incident reports
when there are multiple release and re-engagements of a restraint. The agency is
currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor
CAP complaince with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2023C0000495 with CAP approval date of 7/20/2023 was a
result of the licensing authority not being immediately notified of youths going
AWOL and not being notified within 24 hours of youths having contact with law
enforcement. The agency went over policy and provided a training to all staff. The
agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to
monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2023C0000527 with a CAP approval date of 7/20/2023 was a
result of the facility not immediately reporting youths AWOL to the parents and
referring agencies. The agency had not implemented the previous CAP of
reviewing the policy and providing a training to all staff at the time of this
investigation. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and
DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2023C0000667 with a CAP approval date of 11/6/2023 was a
result of the facility not taking care of the educational concerns to support a youth
4

with their academic achievement, not providing a copy of service plans to the case
manager and parent, not notifying a youth’s worker of a restraint, not reporting
restraints on the MDHHS incident report or the generated MiSACWIS incident
report within the required timeframes and having unwarranted restraints. The
administrative team is reviewing all incidents during the daily management
meetings, the FA and/or Case Manager are sending follow up emails to case
workers and printing the email to show notification was made, and all staff were
trained. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL
continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2023C0000798 with a CAP approval date of 12/18/2023 was
a result of a staff sleeping while on shift and staff using their cell phones for
personal calls while on shift. The agency had staff complete individual corrective
action plans regarding the use of cell phones, staff were terminated, and staff were
trained. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL
continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.

There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
since the last reporting period, the agency was able to identify barriers with the
leadership team staff, issues with staff and youth cultures, lack of communication in
the program, retention of staff, staff not being held accountable and not utilizing de-
escalation skills and trauma informed care when dealing with the youth in a crisis
situation. The facility has implemented internal quality improvement plans to
increase service delivery, improve the quality of programming, and improve
outcomes based on their own internal quarterly reviews. The Chief Administrator
reported positive changes in the program have been creating a positive and safe
staff and youth culture, increased communication in all departments, increase the
utilization of de-escalation strategies and trauma informed care, successful closure
of contract monitoring requirements due to risk score reduction, consistent
achievements of restraint reduction goals, and a full year of zero abuse
substantiations. For the next coming year, the agency will continue to focus on
communication in all departments, de-escalation strategies and trauma informed
care and creating a safe environment for the youth placed.
Staff and Youth Interviews
5

Interviews with staff indicated staff retention is still an issue but they are working on
recruiting events. One of the staff interviewed stated there are a lot of newer staff
so it is important they have good, informative training and are paired with veteran
staff. Staff reported they feel the Chief Administrator does a good job
communicating and providing the tools they need to do their job successfully.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Two youth reported New
Hope was the best facility they have been at while in care. Youth reported staff
care about them, take them on many outings, and talk to them when they are
upset. One youth reported feeling unsafe at times in the program due to the
behaviors of a former youth. This youth reported staff did their best to separate
that youth from the rest of the house. This youth stated she talked with the Chief
Administrator and Therapist about her concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walk through of the facility occurred on May 23, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
